This algorithm works well Algorithm attempt find outward-facing normals: --------------------------------------------------- First, mark faces UNKNOWN. Then create edge dictionary that allows find faces sharing given edge (where edge integers representing shared vertices). Pick arbitrary face mark COUNTER_CLOCKWISE. Using edge dictionary, orient surrounding faces based orientation this face. recurse surrounding faces, consistently orienting entire surface. Find average vertices this surface. Using that point, calculate volume measurement, taking into account face\'s orientation. volume turns positive, assume faces oriented correctly. negative, reverse their orientations (mark them CLOCKWISE). faces still UNKNOWN after this, choose another face through algorithm again. end, faces marked CLOCKWISE must have their indices reversed before facet normals found. (Note: running Silicon Graphics machines IRIS Inventor toolkit developers package have source this algorithm-- /usr/src/Inventor/tools/ivnorm/. you\'re not... sorry, can\'t give source, even could relies heavily Inventor).'

Printing Office (GPO), although more \tinformation would probably needed order them. Minovitch, _The Determination Characteristics Ballistic Interplanetary Trajectories Under Influence Multiple Planetary Attractions_, Technical Report 32-464, Propulsion Laboratory, Pasadena, Calif., Oct, 1963. \tThe title says all. Starts with basics works \tVery good. companion article: Minovitch, _Utilizing Large Planetary Perubations Design Deep-Space Solar-Probe Ecliptic Trajectories_, Technical Report 32-849, JPL, Pasadena, Calif., 1965. \tYou need read first first realy understand this one. \tIt does include _short_ summary only find second. \tContact availability these reports. Spacecraft Attitude Dynamics, Peter Hughes 1986, John Wiley \tSons. Celestial Mechanics: computational guide practitioner, Lawrence Taff, (Wiley-Interscience, York, 1985). \tStarts with basics (2-body problem, coordinates) works \torbit determinations, perturbations, differential corrections. \tTaff also briefly discusses stellar dynamics including short \tdiscussion n-body problems. COMPUTING PLANETARY POSITIONS More references: Flandern Pullinen, _Low-Precision Formulae Planetary Positions_, Astrophysical Supp Series, 41:391-411, 1979. Look astronomy physics library this- also said available from Willmann-Bell. \tGives series compute positions accurate minute \tperiod years from now. Pluto included stated \thave accuracy only about minutes. _Multiyear Interactive Computer Almanac_ (MICA), produced Naval Observatory. Valid years 1990-1999. ($80 outside US). Available (order #PB93-500163HDV) Macintosh (order #PB93-500155HDV). From NTIS sales desk, (703)-487-4650. believe this intended replace USNO\'s Interactive Computer Ephemeris. _Interactive Computer Ephemeris_ (from Naval Observatory) distributed IBM-PC floppy disks, (Willmann-Bell). Covers dates 1800-2049. Planetary Programs Tables from -4000 +2800, Bretagnon Simon 1986, Willmann-Bell. \tFloppy disks available separately. Fundamentals Celestial Mechanics (2nd ed), J.M.A. Danby 1988, Willmann-Bell. good fundamental text. Includes BASIC programs- companion \tfloppy disks available separately. Astronomical Algorithms, Meeus 1991, Willmann-Bell. \tIf actively editions Astronomical Formulae \tfor Calculators, will want replace with Astronomical \tAlgorithms. 'molecules evolved from esoteric academic subject into international industry. Computer graphics played decisive role this transformation allowing chemists build, visualize interact with complex geometrical objects. While computer scientists conversant language their discipline, they often unfamiliar with terminology, simulation techniques practical needs research chemists. Similarly, chemists often unfamiliar with latest paradigms technological advances graphical computing. This interdisciplinary course intended bridge between computer science chemistry equip chemistry researchers wish more than just casual users prepackaged graphics software. Although this intended course computational chemistry drug design, data sets from chemical research problems will used students will encouraged bring data sets their own. exercises projects will carried using data-flow programming (IBM Visualization Data Explorer software) students will have access Cornell Theory Center computing resources, including video recording equipment. Audience: researchers students chemical biological sciences interested integrating state-of-the-art computer graphics into their research- computer scientists wishing gain familiarity with major application scientific visualization. class size will limited participants first-come first-served basis. Level: Graduate/advanced undergraduate, Credits. taken without credit workshop. Calculus, linear algebra introductory chemistry required. Familiarity with Unix, X-windows useful required. Date: June 14-25, 1993 Credits) June 14-18, 1993 credits) Time: Mon-Fri 9:00 12:00 1:00 4:00 Cost: credit $410 credits $820 Format course will held Theory Center training facility where computer workstations will available. Daily lectures will interspersed with laboratory exercises ample time will provided project enablement familiarization with computing environment. Students enrolled credit will graded basis their laboratory exercises short final project. Those enrolled second credit will receive more advanced lectures, given more time project development meet daily share experience discuss problems encountered. Content (may vary) Elements computer graphics polygonal rendering, lighting models, tracing, volumetric rendering, stereo graphics, animation, introduction data-flow programming (DX), interactivity. Representing atom size, time energy scales basic classical quantum mechanics Important categories molecules small molecules, biopolymers, surfaces catalysts, miscellaneous current applications Data formats conversions Advanced molecular graphics techniques Types simulation experiment electronic structure, molecular dynamics/mechanics electrostatics, X-ray crystallography, NMR, quantum dynamics spectroscopy. Instructors course will taught instructors. Topics related computer graphics will handled Bruce Land, Project Leader Visualization, Cornell National Supercomputing Facility. 'FIRST ANNUAL PHIGS USER GROUP CONFERENCE First Annual PHIGS User Group Conference held March 21-24 Orlando, Florida. conference organized Rensse- laer Design Research Center co-operation with IEEE SIG- GRAPH. Attendees came from five countries spanning three con- tinents. good cross-section PHIGS community represented this conference with participants including PHIGS users, workstation vendors, third-party PHIGS implementors, stan- dards committee members, researchers from industry academia. opening speaker, Richard Puk, challenged PHIGS users take charge your PHIGS participating PHIGS standardization activities communicating their needs PHIGS implementors. closing speaker, Andries Dam, described vision future graphics standards beyond PHIGS. Technical paper sessions conference covered following topics: PHIGS Application Toolkits, Application Issues, Texture Mapping, NURBS, PHIGS Extensions, Object-Oriented Libraries Frameworks. Panel sessions PHIGS PEX, PHIGS Non-Retained Data, Real-World Applications Using PHIGS, Portability Issues generated enthusiastic discussions formed good forum exchange ideas, needs, experiences. conference also included full tutorials topics rang- from mathematics graphics object-oriented tools based PHIGS. Next year\'s conference planned March, 1994. PHIGS EVERYWHERE conference, PHIGS vendors described demonstrated PHIGS products that types computers, from mainframes. Megatek Corporation demonstrated their PHIGS extensions including conditional traversal, composite logical input devices, texturing translucency. Template Graphics Software launched FIGARO+ PRO, Photo- Realistic Option PHIGS+. FIGARO+ designed advanced rendering existing PHIGS+ API, with features like tracing, materials, anti-aliasing texture mapping. Radiosity support also planned. FIGARO+ example continues newly emerging graphics features their products. FIGARO+ supports immediate mode extensions PHIGS also supports XGL, Starbase GL/OpenGL. FIGARO+ will released this summer. also demonstrated latest versions FIGraph, powerful 2-call charting system based PHIGS+, FIGt, object- oriented utility library PHIGS/PEX developers. Gallium Software demonstrated version GPHIGS Silicon Graphics workstations. Scheduled summer, 1993, Ver- sion GPHIGS, company\'s PHIGS+ library worksta- tions, will include advanced PHIGS debugger that allows PHIGS developers display browse PHIGS structures other PHIGS internal state. also described their Non-Duplicated Data Store that stores pointers application data GPHIGS more efficient memory. addition, described their application that allows application callback functions during GPHIGS traversal. GPHIGS PHIGURE, G5G\'s data visual- izer application development toolkit, currently available major workstations that support Windows, PEX, Starbase. Wise Software presented slide show Z-PHIGS MS-Windows ARENA, PHIGS based modeller/render. Z-PHIGS implements most PHIGS+ primitives. addition Z-PHIGS built many advanced rendering features like texture mapping, shadow genera- tion, area quick updates tracing. demo disk Z-PHIGS ARENA available request. exhibited GRAFPAK-PHIGS, their full-featured PHIGS implemen- tation based PHIGS. GRAFPAK-PHIGS available most workstation platforms with FORTRAN bindings incor- porates support. Within booth sponsored Advanced Technology Center, Digital Equipment Corporation demonstrated PHIGS V2.4 running 3000/400 PXG. ATCs\' GRAFPAK-PHIGS port PHIGS. PHIGS V2.4 contains most PHIGS PHIGS PLUS features with support V5.1 protocol. PHIGS also contains most GM/EDS PHIGS extensions including post-to-view well proprietary extensions support immediate mode rendering PHIGS environment. AXP, DEC, PHIGS trademarks Digital Equipment Cor- poration. GRAFPAK-PHIGS trademarks Advanced Tech- nology Center. trademarks Massachusetts Insti- tute Technology. exhibit featured accelerator attached workstation running graPHIGS PEX. Hewlett Packard SHOgraphics demonstrated conference. Hewlett Packard machine coupled display SHOgraphics terminal. showcased their latest PHIGS product enhance- ments. PHIGS USER GROUP PHIGS Users Group formed development PHIGS applications provide user feedback PHIGS implementors PHIGS standards bodies. more information about PHIGS Users Group, send e-mail phigsug@cadrt10.me.vt.edu write Sankar Jayaram Virginia Polytechnic Institute Randolph Hall Blacksburg, 24061-0238 FAX: 703-231-9100 VENDOR CONTACTS Megatek Corporation (619) 455-5590 (619) 453-7603 Template Graphics Software (800) 544-4847 (619) 452-2547 WISE software GmbH +49-451-3909-413 +49-451-3909-499 North American Sales (800) 267-2626 (613) 592-1278 Advanced Technology Center (800) 999-5711 (714) 583-9213 Digital Equipment Corporation (603) 884-5111 International Business Machines Corporation (800) 426-3333 Hewlett Packard Company (303) 229-3800 COPIES CONFERENCE PROCEEDINGS Copies conference proceedings obtained contact- Mary Johnson Johnson, Mary Design Manufacturing Institute Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute Eighth Street Building CII, Room 7015 Troy, 12180-3590 Tel: (518)276-6754 Fax: (518)276-2702 Email: mjohnson@rdrc.rpi.edu

'Intro ACCESS.bus (RE: ACCESS.bus Software Creator\'s \tContest Announcement) WHAT ACCESS.bus? ACCESS.bus open industry standard computer peripheral connectivity. ACCESS.bus serial protocol that uses simple, low-cost technology link multiple devices single port. Peripheral devices such keyboards keypads, locators (Mice, Trackballs, Joysticks), printers, gloves, digitizers, sensors, actuators data transmitters others easily daisy chained host Applications such CAD/CAM, Data Acquisition, Simulation, Virtual Reality, Multiple-Player/Single Games, Education many, many more take advantage ACCESS.bus, technology that puts Plug Play every ACCESS.bus offers advantages end-users developers systems peripherals. Multiple devices connect host computer with only port. Common communication methods number device types lead simplified hardware software development. open standard, ACCESS.bus enables cross- platform same device. ACCESS.bus TECHNOLOGICAL DESCRIPTION: ===================================== ACCESS.bus technology open specification, enabling anyone implement host systems peripheral devices without royalty. ACCESS.bus topology architecture. That single host accommodate peripheral devices. ACCESS.bus data rate Kbits/sec. ACCESS.bus Physical Layer ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ ACCESS.bus serial architecture, based hardware protocol, with data line clock line. Standard low-cost microcontrollers handle bit-level handshaking, including automatic arbitration clock synchronization. ACCESS.bus Software Protocols ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ ACCESS.bus communication protocol composed three levels: Protocol, Base Protocol, Application Protocol. PROTOCOL: This simple efficient protocol defines arbitration among contending masters without losing data. provides cooperative synchronization partners with different clock rates. transactions include addressing, framing bits into bytes, byte acknowledgment receiver. BASE PROTOCOL: Establishes asymmetrical interconnect between host computer multiple peripherals. host becomes ACCESS.bus manager. Base Protocol defines format ACCESS.bus message envelope, which transaction with additional semantics, including checksum. Unique features Base Protocol auto-addressing plugging. Auto-addressing assigns devices with unique addresses, without need setting jumpers switches. plugging ability attach detach devices while system running, without rebooting. APPLICATION PROTOCOL: This highest level ACCESS.bus protocol which defines message semantics specific particular types devices. Each type requires different Application Protocol. Rotating raster image arbitrary angle. obvious wrong method loop over pixels source image, transform each coordinate, copy pixel destination. This wrong because leaves holes destination. Instead, loop over pixels destination image, apply *reverse* transformation coordinates, copy that pixel from source. This method quite general, used one-to-one mapping, just rotation. anti-aliasing doing sub-pixel sampling. However, there much faster method, with antialising included, which involves doing three shear operations. method originally created Raster Toolkit (see below)- implementation also present PBMPLUS. Reference: Fast Algorithm Raster Rotation, Alan Paeth (awpaeth@watcgl.waterloo.edu) Graphics Interface \'86 (Vancouver). article toolkit appears same journal. updated version rotation paper appears Graphics Gems (see section [1]) under original title. JPEG (pronounced jay-peg) standardized image compression mechanism. JPEG stands Joint Photographic Experts Group, original name committee that wrote standard. JPEG designed compressing either full-color gray-scale digital images natural, real-world scenes. does work well non-realistic images, such cartoons line drawings. JPEG does handle black-and-white (1-bit-per-pixel) images, does handle motion picture compression. Standards compressing those types images being worked other committees, named JBIG MPEG respectively. JPEG lossy, meaning that image decompression isn\'t quite identical what originally algorithm achieves much compression exploiting known limitations human eye, notably fact that small color details aren\'t perceived well small details light-and-dark. Thus, JPEG intended compressing images that will looked humans. plan machine-analyze your images, small errors introduced JPEG problem you, even they invisible eye. useful property JPEG that degree lossiness varied adjusting compression parameters. This means that image maker trade file size against output image quality. make *extremely* small files don\'t mind poor quality- this useful indexing image archives, making thumbnail views icons, etc. etc. Conversely, aren\'t happy with output quality default compression setting, jack quality until satisfied, accept lesser compression. JPEG? There good reasons: make your image files smaller, store 24-bit-per-pixel color data instead 8-bit-per-pixel data. Making image files smaller transmitting files across networks archiving libraries images. Being able compress Mbyte full-color file down Kbytes makes difference disk space transmission time! comparing JPEG, size ratio more like four one. 'This file other text image files from missions available from Info public access computer site, reachable Internet anonymous pubinfo.jpl.nasa.gov (128.149.6.2)- dialup modem (818) 354-1333, 9600 bits second, parameters N-8-1. ----------------------------------------------------------------- Solar System Glance Information Summary 010-A (JPL) June 1991 410-34-1 6/91 NASA National Aeronautics Space Administration Propulsion Laboratory California Institue Technology Pasadena, California printed copy this publication contact public mail office NASA center your geographic region. INTRODUCTION From small world have gazed upon cosmic ocean untold thousands years. Ancient astronomers observed points light that appeared move among stars. They called these objects planets, meaning wanderers, named them after Roman deities Jupiter, king gods- Mars, war- Mercury, messenger gods- Venus, love beauty, Saturn, father Jupiter agriculture. stargazers also observed comets with sparkling tails, meteors shooting stars apparently falling from sky. Science flourished during European Renaissance. Fundamental physical laws governing planetary motion were discovered, orbits planets around were calculated. 17th century, astronomers pointed device called telescope heavens made startling discoveries. years since 1959 have amounted golden solar system exploration. Advancements rocketry after World enabled machines break grip Earth\'s gravity travel Moon other planets. United States sent automated spacecraft, then human-crewed expeditions, explore Moon. automated machines have orbited landed Venus Mars- explored Sun\'s environment- observed comets, made close-range surveys while flying past Mercury, Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus Neptune. These travelers brought quantum leap knowledge understanding solar system. Through electronic sight other senses automated spacecraft, color complexion have been given worlds that centuries appeared Earth-bound eyes fuzzy disks indistinct points light. dozens previously unknown objects have been discovered. Future historians will likely view these pioneering flights through solar system some most remarkable achievements 20th century. AUTOMATED SPACECRAFT National Aeronautics Space Administration\'s (NASA\'s) automated spacecraft solar system exploration come many shapes sizes. While they designed fulfill separate specific mission objectives, craft share much common. Each spacecraft consists various scientific instruments selected particular mission, supported basic subsystems electrical power, trajectory orientation control, well processing data communicating with Earth. Electrical power required operate spacecraft instruments systems. NASA uses both solar energy from arrays photovoltaic cells small nuclear generators power solar system missions. Rechargeable batteries employed backup supplemental power. Imagine that spacecraft successfully journeyed millions miles through space time near planet, only have cameras other sensing instruments pointed wrong speeds past target! help prevent such mishap, subsystem small thrusters used control spacecraft. thrusters linked with devices that maintain constant gaze selected stars. Just Earth\'s early seafarers used stars navigate oceans, spacecraft stars maintain their bearings space. With subsystem locked onto fixed points reference, flight controllers keep spacecraft\'s scientific instruments pointed target body craft\'s communications antennas pointed toward Earth. thrusters also used fine-tune flight path speed spacecraft ensure that target body encountered planned distance proper trajectory. Between 1959 1971, NASA spacecraft were dispatched study Moon solar environment- they also scanned inner planets other than Earth Mercury, Venus Mars. These three worlds, own, known terrestrial planets because they share solid-rock composition. early planetary reconnaissance missions, NASA employed highly successful series spacecraft called Mariners. Their flights helped shape planning later missions. Between 1962 1975, seven Mariner missions conducted first surveys planetary neighbors space. Mariners used solar panels their primary power source. first final versions spacecraft wings covered with photovoltaic cells. Other Mariners were equipped with four solar panels extending from their octagonal bodies. Although Mariners ranged from Mariner Venus spacecraft, weighing kilograms (447 pounds), Mariner Mars Orbiter, weighing kilograms (2,147 pounds), their basic design remained quite similar throughout program. Mariner Venus spacecraft, example, originally been backup Mariner Mars flyby. Mariner spacecraft sent Venus Mercury used components left over from Mariner Mars Orbiter program. 1972, NASA launched Pioneer Jupiter spacecraft. Interest shifting four outer planets Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus Neptune giant balls dense quite different from terrestrial worlds already surveyed. Four NASA spacecraft Pioneers Voyagers were sent 1970s tour outer regions solar system. Because distances involved, these travelers took anywhere from months years reach their destinations. Barring faster spacecraft, they will eventually become first human artifacts journey distant stars. When should JPEG, when should stick with GIF? well does JPEG compress images? What good quality settings JPEG? Where JPEG software? [14] What some rules thumb converting images JPEG? Sections basic info that every JPEG user needs know- sections 7-14 advanced info curious. This article posted every weeks. always find latest version news.answers archive rtfm.mit.edu (18.172.1.27). FTP, fetch /pub/usenet/news.answers/jpeg-faq- don\'t have FTP, send e-mail mail-server@rtfm.mit.edu with body send usenet/news.answers/jpeg-faq. Many other articles also stored this archive. more instructions archive, send e-mail same address with words help index quotes) separate lines. don\'t reply, server misreading your return address- line such path myname@mysite specify your correct e-mail address reply ---------- What JPEG? JPEG (pronounced jay-peg) standardized image compression mechanism. JPEG stands Joint Photographic Experts Group, original name committee that wrote standard. JPEG designed compressing either full-color gray-scale digital images natural, real-world scenes. does work well non-realistic images, such cartoons line drawings. JPEG does handle black-and-white (1-bit-per-pixel) images, does handle motion picture compression. Standards compressing those types images being worked other committees, named JBIG MPEG respectively. JPEG lossy, meaning that image decompression isn\'t quite identical what originally algorithm achieves much compression exploiting known limitations human eye, notably fact that small color details aren\'t perceived well small details light-and-dark. Thus, JPEG intended compressing images that will looked humans. plan machine-analyze your images, small errors introduced JPEG problem you, even they invisible eye. useful property JPEG that degree lossiness varied adjusting compression parameters. This means that image maker trade file size against output image quality. make *extremely* small files don\'t mind poor quality- this useful indexing image archives, making thumbnail views icons, etc. etc. Conversely, aren\'t happy with output quality default compression setting, jack quality until satisfied, accept lesser compression. JPEG? There good reasons: make your image files smaller, store 24-bit-per-pixel color data instead 8-bit-per-pixel data. Making image files smaller transmitting files across networks archiving libraries images. Being able compress Mbyte full-color file down Kbytes makes difference disk space transmission time! comparing JPEG, size ratio more like four one. More details below.) your viewing software doesn\'t support JPEG directly, you\'ll have convert JPEG some other format viewing manipulating images. Even with JPEG-capable viewer, takes longer decode view JPEG image than view image simpler format (GIF, instance). Thus, using JPEG essentially time/space tradeoff: give some time order store transmit image more cheaply. It\'s worth noting that when network phone transmission involved, time savings from transferring shorter file much greater than extra time decompress file. I\'ll arithmetic yourself. other reason JPEG will gradually replace standard Usenet posting format that JPEG store full color information: bits/pixel million colors) instead less (256 fewer colors). have only 8-bit display hardware then this seem like much advantage you. Within couple years, though, 8-bit will look obsolete black-and-white MacPaint format does today. Furthermore, reasons detailed section JPEG more useful than exchanging images among people with widely varying color display hardware. Hence JPEG considerably more appropriate than Usenet posting standard. When should JPEG, when should stick with GIF? JPEG *not* going displace entirely- some types images, superior image quality, file size, both. first things learn about JPEG which kinds images apply rule thumb, JPEG superior storing full-color gray-scale images realistic scenes- that means scanned photographs similar material. JPEG superior even don\'t have 24-bit display hardware, superior (See section details.) does significantly better images with only distinct colors, such cartoons line drawings. particular, large areas pixels that *exactly* same color compressed very efficiently indeed GIF. JPEG can\'t squeeze these files much does without introducing visible defects. This sort image best kept form. particular, single-color borders quite cheap files, they should avoided JPEG files.) JPEG also hard time with very sharp edges: pure-black pixels adjacent pure-white pixels, example. Sharp edges tend come blurred unless very high quality setting. Again, this sort thing found scanned photographs, shows fairly often files: borders, overlaid text, etc. blurriness particularly objectionable with text that\'s only pixels high. have with small-size overlaid text, don\'t JPEG Computer-drawn images (ray-traced scenes, instance) usually fall between scanned images cartoons terms complexity. more complex subtly rendered image, more likely that JPEG will well same goes semi-realistic artwork (fantasy drawings such). Plain black-and-white (two level) images should never converted JPEG. need least about gray levels before JPEG useful gray-scale images. should also noted that lossless gray-scale images levels, while JPEG not. have existing library images, wonder whether should convert them JPEG. will lose little image quality (Section which argues that JPEG image quality superior GIF, only applies both formats start from full-color original. start from GIF, you\'ve already irretrievably lost great deal information- JPEG only make things worse.) However, disk space savings justify converting anyway. This decision you\'ll have make yourself. convert library JPEG, section hints. prepared leave some images format, since some GIFs will convert well. well does JPEG compress images? Pretty darn well. Here some sample file sizes image have handy, 727x525 full-color image ship harbor. first three files comparison purposes- rest were created with free JPEG software described section File\t Size bytes\t\tComments ship.ppm\t1145040 Original file format compression- bits \t\t\t bytes pixel, plus bytes overhead) ship.ppm.Z\t 963829 file passed through Unix compress \t\t\t compress doesn\'t accomplish lot, you\'ll note. \t\t\t Other text-oriented compressors give similar results. ship.gif\t 240438 Converted with ppmquant ppmtogif \t\t\t Most savings result losing color \t\t\t info: saves bits/pixel, (See sec. ship.jpg95\t 155622 cjpeg (highest useful quality setting) \t\t\t This indistinguishable from 24-bit original, \t\t\t least nonprofessional eyeballs. ship.jpg75\t 58009 cjpeg (default setting) \t\t\t have look mighty darn close distinguish this \t\t\t from original, even with both on-screen once. ship.jpg50\t 38406 cjpeg \t\t\t This slight defects- know what look \t\t\t for, could tell it\'s been JPEGed without seeing \t\t\t original. Still good image quality many \t\t\t recent postings Usenet pictures groups. ship.jpg25\t 25192 cjpeg \t\t\t JPEG\'s characteristic blockiness becomes apparent \t\t\t this setting (djpeg -blocksmooth helps some). \t\t\t Still, I\'ve seen plenty Usenet postings that were \t\t\t poorer image quality than this. ship.jpg5o\t 6587 cjpeg -optimize (-optimize cuts table overhead) \t\t\t Blocky, perfectly satisfactory preview \t\t\t indexing purposes. Note that this file TINY: \t\t\t compression ratio from original 173:1 this case JPEG make file that\'s factor four five smaller than comparable quality (the file every good GIF, better have full-color display). This seems typical ratio real-world scenes. What good quality settings JPEG? Most JPEG compressors pick file size image quality tradeoff selecting quality setting. There seems widespread confusion about meaning these settings. Quality does mean keep 95\% information, some have claimed. quality scale purely arbitrary- it\'s percentage anything. name game using JPEG pick lowest quality setting (smallest file size) that decompresses into image indistinguishable from original. This setting will vary from image another from observer another, here some rules thumb. default quality setting very often best choice. This setting about lowest without expecting defects typical image. first- defects, then Except experimental purposes, never above saying will produce file three times large hardly better quality. image less than perfect quality begin with, might able down without objectionable degradation. other hand, might need HIGHER quality setting avoid further degradation. second case seems apply much time when converting GIFs JPEG. default about right compressing 24-bit images, usually better converting GIFs (see section more info). want very small file (say preview indexing purposes) prepared tolerate large defects, setting range about right. amusing art. [6A] looking canned software, viewers, etc: first part this list system-specific programs that only kind system. don\'t what want your machine, check portable JPEG software described list. Note that this list concentrates free shareware programs that obtain over Internet- some commercial programs listed too. Windows: John Bradley\'s free (version 2.00 excellent viewer JPEG, GIF, other image formats. It\'s available from export.lcs.mit.edu ftp.cis.upenn.edu. file called \'xv-???.tar.Z\' (where version number, currently 2.21)- located \'contrib\' directory export \'pub/xv\' directory upenn. reduces images bits internally, which means it\'s real good choice have 24-bit display (you\'ll still only 8-bit color). Also, shouldn\'t convert full-color images JPEG, because they\'ll color-quantized first. fine tool converting other 8-bit images JPEG. CAUTION: there glitch versions 2.21 earlier: sure check save normal size checkbox when saving JPEG file, file will blurry. Another good choice Windows John Cristy\'s free ImageMagick package, also available from export.lcs.mit.edu, file contrib/ImageMagick.tar.Z. This package handles many image processing conversion tasks. ImageMagick viewer handles 24-bit displays correctly- colormapped displays, does better (though slower) color quantization than basic free JPEG software. Both above large, complex packages. just want simple image viewer, xloadimage xli. xloadimage supports JPEG latest release, 3.03. xloadimage free available from export.lcs.mit.edu, file contrib/xloadimage.3.03.tar.Z. variant version xloadimage, said fans somewhat faster more robust than original. (The current indeed faster more robust than current xloadimage, least with respect JPEG files, because decoder while xloadimage 3.03 using hacked-over next xloadimage release will this.) also free available from export.lcs.mit.edu, file contrib/xli.1.14.tar.Z. Both programs said right thing with 24-bit displays. MS-DOS: This covers plain DOS- Windows OS/2 programs, next headings. good choice Eric Praetzel\'s free DVPEG, which views JPEG files. current version, 2.4a, available from sunee.uwaterloo.ca (129.97.50.50), file pub/jpeg/viewers/dvpeg24a.zip. This good basic viewer that works either 386/486 machines. user interface flashy, it\'s functional. Another freeware JPEG/GIF/TGA viewer Mohammad Rezaei\'s Hiview. current version, 1.2, available from Simtel20 mirror sites (see NOTE below), file msdos/graphics/hv12.zip. Hiview requires better VCPI-compatible memory manager (QEMM386 386MAX work- Windows OS/2 not). Hiview currently fastest viewer images that bigger than your screen. larger images, scales image down screen (rather than using panning/scrolling most viewers do). prefer this approach, there\'s denying that slows down loading large images considerably. Note: installation tricky- read directions carefully! shareware alternative ColorView ($30). This easier install than either freeware alternatives. user interface also much spiffier-looking, although personally find harder more keystrokes, inconsistent behavior. faster than DVPEG little slower than Hiview, least hardware. (For images larger than screen size, DVPEG ColorView seem about same speed, both faster than Hiview.) current version 2.1, available from Simtel20 mirror sites (see NOTE below), file msdos/graphics/dcview21.zip. Requires VESA graphics driver- don\'t have one, look vesadrv2.zip vesa-tsr.zip from same directory. (Many recent have built-in VESA driver, don\'t load VESA driver unless ColorView complains that driver missing.) second shareware alternative Fullview, which been kicking around while, don\'t know stable archive location current (rather old) version inferior above viewers anyway. author tells that version Fullview will shortly will submitted Simtel20 archives that time. well-known viewer CompuShow (CSHOW) supports JPEG latest revision, 8.60a. However, CSHOW\'s JPEG implementation isn\'t very good: it\'s slow (about half speed above viewers) image quality poor except hi-color displays. it\'d have been nice good JPEG capability CSHOW. Shareware, $25. Available from Simtel20 mirror sites (see NOTE below), file msdos/gif/cshw860a.zip. remarkable variety graphics hardware, these viewers might work your particular machine. can\'t *any* them work, you\'ll need following conversion programs convert JPEG GIF, then view with your favorite viewer. have hi-color hardware, don\'t intermediate format- find TARGA-capable viewer instead. VPIC5.0 reputed right thing with hi-color displays.) Independent JPEG Group\'s free JPEG converters FTPable from Simtel20 mirror sites (see NOTE below), file msdos/graphics/jpeg4.zip jpeg4386.zip have extended memory). These files compilations free source code described section they will convert JPEG from GIF, Targa, formats. Handmade Software offers free JPEG<=>GIF conversion tools, GIF2JPG/JPG2GIF. These slow limited conversion from format- particular, can\'t 24-bit color output from JPEG. major advantage these tools that they will read write HSI\'s proprietary JPEG format well Usenet-standard JFIF format. Since HSI-format files rather widespread BBSes, this useful capability. JPEG (pronounced jay-peg) standardized image compression mechanism. JPEG stands Joint Photographic Experts Group, original name committee that wrote standard. This means that image maker trade file size against output image quality. make *extremely* small files don\'t mind poor quality- this useful indexing image archives, making thumbnail views icons, etc. etc. Conversely, aren\'t happy with output quality default compression setting, jack quality until satisfied, accept lesser compression. JPEG? There good reasons: make your image files smaller, store 24-bit-per-pixel color data instead 8-bit-per-pixel data. Making image files smaller transmitting files across networks archiving libraries images. Path: dime!ymir.cs.umass.edu!nic.umass.edu!noc.near.net!howland.reston.ans.net!usc!elroy.jpl.nasa.gov!decwrl!waikato.ac.nz!ldo From: ldo@waikato.ac.nz (Lawrence D\'Oliveiro, Waikato University) Newsgroups: comp.multimedia,comp.graphics Date: 05:09:15 References: <1993Mar31.074502.3590@aragorn.unibe.ch> <1993Apr16.212441.34125@rchland.ibm.com> Organization: University Waikato, Hamilton, Zealand Lines: Xref: dime comp.multimedia:6358 comp.graphics:32606 with discussion about observed playback speeds with QuickTime, effects scaling thought I\'d some more tests. First all, felt that original speed test perhaps less than realistic. movie been using only frames version very first movie created with Compact Video compressor). decided something little longer would give closer real-world results (for better worse). pulled copy 2001: Space Odyssey that recorded while back. About fifteen minutes into movie, there\'s sequence where Earth shuttle approaching space station. Specifically, digitized portion about seconds\' duration, zooming rotating space station. figured this would give reasonable amount movement between frames. increase differences between frames, digitized only frames second, give total frames. captured footage resolution 384*288 pixels with Spigot card Centris (quarter-size resolution from source). then imported into Premiere through Compact Video compressor, keeping frame rate. created versions movie: scaled 320*240 resolution, other 160*120 resolution. used default 2.00 quality setting Premiere 2.0.1, specified frame every frames. then 320*240 movie through same Speed Test program used results I\'d been reporting earlier. Result: playback rate over frames second. That\'s right, getting much higher result than with that first short test movie. Just fun, copied 320*240 movie external hard disk Quantum LP105S), from there. This time playback rate only about frames second. Obviously 230MB internal hard disk (also Quantum) significant contributor speed playback. modified speed test program allow specification optional scaling factors, tried playing back 160*120 movie scaled 320*240 size. This time playback speed over fps. Clearly, poster observed poor performance scaled playback seeing QuickTime action, 1.5. I\'d tests with QuickTime 1.0, don\'t think it\'s entirely compatible with Centris System 7.1... Unscaled, playback rate 160*120 movie over fps. other thing tried saving versions 320*240 movie with preferred playback rates greater than 1.0, seeing well they played from within MoviePlayer with QuickTime\'s normal synchronized playback). preferred rate fps) didn\'t work well: playback very jerky. Compare this with speed test, which achieved with ease. can\'t believe that QuickTime\'s synchronization code would this much overhead: think slowdown coming from system\'s task switching. preferred rate fps) seemed work fine: couldn\'t evidence stutter. fps) *think* could slight stutter, with four frames every second, hard tell. guess could recreating movies with longer interval between frames, make stutter more noticeable. course, this will also improve compression slightly, which should speed playback performance even more... Lawrence D\'Oliveiro fone: +64-7-856-2889 Computer Services Dept fax: +64-7-838-4066 University Waikato electric mail: ldo@waikato.ac.nz Hamilton, Zealand 47\' 175^ 19\' GMT+12:00 I\'m afraid missed start this thread, there three factors that significantly affect QuickTime\'s playback speed that want take into account: playback depth (things fastest when play movie back depth compressed for, this usually bit, other depths course) possible). type scaling optimized double size scaling, other scaling factors peformance much harder). playback window position (MoviePlayer limits your window placement choices advantagous pixel boundaries default, I\'m sure about Premiere). combination those radically alter playback performance. Image size course, another biggie. Giving movie player lots also make real difference. Forgive these were mentioned earlier thread... -Peter

After about parabolas, discovered that performing tricks I\'ve discovered keep myself from getting motion sickness- keeping head very still moving very slowly except hands arms, which needed rapid, concious motion experiment. During pull-out parabola queasiness finally started those air-sickness bags. basically useless rest that flight, went seats back plane while partner (whom drafted just this purpose) kept working experiment while ill. vetran Vomit Comet rider, those anomalous people don\'t sick thing.) didn\'t think constant sensation falling much like swimming air. It\'s very close sensations feel when I\'m scuba diving turn head down fins Jerry: >And what motion sickness >that some astronauts occasionally experience? Some people more prone than others, like some people more prone sick roller coaster ride than others. mental part usually induced lack clear indication which down, Shuttle normally oriented with cargo pointed towards Earth, Earth ground) above head astronauts. 'Archive-name: space/new_probes Last-modified: $Date: 93/04/01 14:39:17 UPCOMING PLANETARY PROBES MISSIONS SCHEDULES Information upcoming currently active missions mentioned below would welcome. Sources: NASA fact sheets, Cassini Mission Design team, ISAS/NASDA launch schedules, press kits. ASUKA (ASTRO-D) ISAS (Japan) X-ray astronomy satellite, launched into Earth orbit 2/20/93. Equipped with large-area wide-wavelength (1-20 Angstrom) X-ray telescope, X-ray cameras, imaging scintillation proportional counters. CASSINI Saturn orbiter Titan atmosphere probe. Cassini joint NASA/ESA project designed accomplish exploration Saturnian system with Cassini Saturn Orbiter Huygens Titan Probe. Cassini scheduled launch aboard Titan IV/Centaur October 1997. After gravity assists Venus, Earth Jupiter VVEJGA trajectory, spacecraft will arrive Saturn June 2004. Upon arrival, Cassini spacecraft performs several maneuvers achieve orbit around Saturn. Near this initial orbit, Huygens Probe separates from Orbiter descends through atmosphere Titan. Orbiter relays Probe data Earth about hours while Probe enters traverses cloudy atmosphere surface. After completion Probe mission, Orbiter continues touring Saturnian system three half years. Titan synchronous orbit trajectories will allow about flybys Titan targeted flybys Iapetus, Dione Enceladus. objectives mission threefold: conduct detailed studies Saturn\'s atmosphere, rings magnetosphere- conduct close-up studies Saturn\'s satellites, characterize Titan\'s atmosphere surface. most intriguing aspects Titan possibility that surface covered part with lakes liquid hydrocarbons that result from photochemical processes upper atmosphere. These hydrocarbons condense form global smog layer eventually rain down onto surface. Cassini orbiter will onboard radar peer through Titan\'s clouds determine there liquid surface. Experiments aboard both orbiter entry probe will investigate chemical processes that produce this unique atmosphere. Cassini mission named Jean Dominique Cassini (1625-1712), first director Paris Observatory, discovered several Saturn\'s satellites major division rings. Titan atmospheric entry probe named Dutch physicist Christiaan Huygens (1629-1695), discovered Titan first described true nature Saturn\'s rings. Scheduled Dates Cassini Mission (VVEJGA Trajectory) ------------------------------------------------------------- 10/06/97 Titan IV/Centaur Launch 04/21/98 Venus Gravity Assist 06/20/99 Venus Gravity Assist 08/16/99 Earth Gravity Assist 12/30/00 Jupiter Gravity Assist 06/25/04 Saturn Arrival 01/09/05 Titan Probe Release 01/30/05 Titan Probe Entry 06/25/08 Primary Mission (Schedule last updated 7/22/92) GALILEO Jupiter orbiter atmosphere probe, transit. returned first resolved images asteroid, Gaspra, while transit Jupiter. Efforts unfurl stuck High-Gain Antenna (HGA) have essentially been abandoned. developed backup plan using data compression (JPEG-like images, lossless compression data from other instruments) which should allow mission achieve approximately 70\% original objectives. Galileo Schedule ---------------- 10/18/89 Launch from Space Shuttle 02/09/90 Venus Flyby 10/**/90 Venus Data Playback 12/08/90 Earth Flyby 05/01/91 High Gain Antenna Unfurled 07/91 06/92 Asteroid Belt Passage 10/29/91 Asteroid Gaspra Flyby 12/08/92 Earth Flyby 05/93 11/93 Asteroid Belt Passage 08/28/93 Asteroid Flyby 07/02/95 Probe Separation 07/09/95 Orbiter Deflection Maneuver 12/95 10/97 Orbital Tour Jovian Moons 12/07/95 Jupiter/Io Encounter 07/18/96 Ganymede 09/28/96 Ganymede 12/12/96 Callisto 01/23/97 Europa 02/28/97 Ganymede 04/22/97 Europa 05/31/97 Europa 10/05/97 Jupiter Magnetotail Exploration HITEN Japanese (ISAS) lunar probe launched 1/24/90. made multiple lunar flybys. Released Hagoromo, smaller satellite, into lunar orbit. This mission made Japan third nation orbit satellite around Moon. MAGELLAN Venus radar mapping mission. mapped almost entire surface high resolution. Currently (4/93) collecting global gravity map. MARS OBSERVER Mars orbiter including m/pixel resolution camera. Launched 9/25/92 Titan III/TOS booster. currently (4/93) transit Mars, arriving 8/24/93. Operations will start 11/93 martian year (687 days). TOPEX/Poseidon Joint US/French Earth observing satellite, launched 8/10/92 Ariane booster. primary objective TOPEX/POSEIDON project make precise accurate global observations level several years, substantially increasing understanding global ocean dynamics. satellite also will increase understanding heat transported ocean. ULYSSES- European Space Agency probe study from orbit over poles. Launched late 1990, carries particles-and-fields experiments (such magnetometer, electron collectors various energy ranges, plasma wave radio receivers, etc.) camera. Since human-built rocket hefty enough send Ulysses ecliptic plane, went Jupiter instead, stole energy from that planet sliding over Jupiter\'s north pole gravity-assist manuver February 1992. This bent path into solar orbit tilted about degrees ecliptic. will pass over Sun\'s south pole summer 1993. aphelion and, surprisingly, perihelion about AU-- that\'s right, solar-studies spacecraft that\'s always further from than Earth While Jupiter\'s neigborhood, Ulysses studied magnetic radiation environment. short summary these results, *Science*, 257, 1487-1489 September 1992). gory technical detail, many articles same issue. OTHER SPACE SCIENCE MISSIONS (note: this based posting Baalke 11/89, with ISAS/NASDA information contributed Yoshiro Yamada (yamada@yscvax.ysc.go.jp). I\'m attempting track changes based updated shuttle manifests- corrections updates welcome. 1993 Missions ALEXIS [spring, Pegasus] ALEXIS (Array Low-Energy X-ray Imaging Sensors) perform wide-field survey soft (low-energy) X-ray spectrum. will scan entire every months search variations soft-X-ray emission from sources such white dwarfs, cataclysmic variable stars flare stars. will also search nearby space such exotic objects isolated neutron stars gamma-ray bursters. ALEXIS project Alamos National Laboratory primarily technology development mission that uses astrophysical sources demonstrate technology. Contact project investigator Jeffrey Bloch (jjb@beta.lanl.gov) more information. Wind [Aug, Delta rocket] Satellite measure solar wind input magnetosphere. Space Radar [Sep, STS-60 SRL-01] Gather radar images Earth\'s surface. Total Ozone Mapping Spectrometer [Dec, Pegasus rocket] Study Stratospheric ozone. (Space Flyer Unit) [ISAS] Conducting space experiments observations this recovered after conducts various scientific engineering experiments. launched ISAS retrieved U.S. Space Shuttle STS-68 1994. 1994 Polar Auroral Plasma Physics [May, Delta rocket] June, measure solar wind ions gases surrounding Earth. IML-2 (STS) [NASDA, 1994 IML-02] International Microgravity Laboratory. ADEOS [NASDA] Advanced Earth Observing Satellite. MUSES-B Space Engineering Satellite-B) [ISAS] Conducting research precise mechanism space structure in-space astronomical observations electromagnetic waves. 1995 \tLUNAR-A [ISAS] Elucidating crust structure thermal construction moon\'s interior. Proposed Missions: Advanced X-ray Astronomy Facility (AXAF) Possible launch from shuttle 1995, AXAF space observatory with high resolution telescope. would orbit years study mysteries fate universe. Earth Observing System (EOS) Possible launch 1997, orbiting space platforms provide long-term data years) Earth systems science including planetary evolution. Mercury Observer Possible 1997 launch. Lunar Observer Possible 1997 launch, would sent into long-term lunar orbit. Observer, from miles above moon\'s poles, would survey characteristics provide global context results from Apollo program. Space Infrared Telescope Facility Possible launch shuttle 1999, this element Great Observatories program. free-flying observatory with lifetime years, would observe comets other primitive bodies outer solar system, study cosmic birth formation galaxies, stars planets distant infrared-emitting galaxies Mars Rover Sample Return (MRSR) Robotics rover would return samples Mars\' atmosphere surface Earch analysis. Possible launch dates: 1996 imaging orbiter, 2001 rover. Fire Possible launch 2001, will gravity assist flyby Earth 2003, final gravity assist from Jupiter 2005, where probe will split into Fire components: Fire probe will journey into Sun, taking measurements star\'s upper atmosphere until vaporized intense heat. probe will head towards Pluto, reaching tiny world study 2016.

'====================================================================== ACM/SIGGRAPH: UNDERSTANDING IMAGES ====================================================================== SUBJECT: Pace University/SIGGRAPH Conference UNDERSTANDING IMAGES =========================================================== purpose this conference bring together breadth disciplines, including physical, biological computational sciences, technology, art, psychology, philosophy, education, order define discuss issues essential image understanding within computer graphics context. FEATURED TOPICS INCLUDE: Psychology/Perception Image Analysis Design Text Sound Philosophy DATE: Friday Saturday, 21-22 1993 TIME: 9:00 6:00 PLACE: Pace Downtown Theater Pace Plaza Spruce Street between Park Gold Street) 10038 FEES: PRE-REGISTRATION (Prior 1993): Members $55.00 Non-Members $75.00 Students $40.00 (Proof Status Required) REGISTRATION (After 1993 On-Site): Attendees $95.00 (Registration Includes Brakfast, Breaks Lunch) SEND REGISTRATION INFORMATION FEES Francis Marchese Computer Science Department NYC/ACM SIGGRAPH Conference Pace University Pace Plaza (Room T-1704) York 10036 voice: (212) 346-1803 fax: (212) 346-1933 email: MARCHESF@PACEVM.bitnet ====================================================================== REGISTRATION INFORMATION: Name _________________________________________________________________ Title ________________________________________________________________ Company ______________________________________________________________ Street Address _______________________________________________________ City ________________________________State____________Zip_____________ Phone (___) ___-____ Evening Phone (___) ___-____ Phone (___) ___-____ Email_____________________________________ ====================================================================== DETAILED DESCRIPTION: ===================== Artists, designers, scientists, engineers educators share problem moving information from mind another. Traditionally, they have used pictures, words, demonstrations, music dance communicate imagery. However, expressing complex notions such infinity seemingly well defined concept such flower present challenges which exceed their technical skills. explosive computers visualization expression tools compounded this problem. hypermedia, multimedia virtual reality systems vast amounts information confront observer participant. Wading through multitude simultaneous images sounds possibly unfamiliar representions, confounded user asks: What does mean? Since image construction, transmission, reception, decipherment ultimate understanding complex tasks, strongly influenced physiology, education culture- and, since electronic media radically amplify each processing step, then electronic communicators, must determine fundamental paradigms composing imagery understanding. Therefore, purpose this conference bring together breadth disciplines, including, limited physical, biological computational sciences, technology, art, psychology, philosophy, education, order define discuss issues essential image understanding within computer graphics context. FEATURED SPEAKERS INCLUDE: Psychology/Perception: Marc May, University Ghent Beverly Jones, University Oregon Barbara Tversky, Standfor University Michael Shiffer, Hubbard, Ohio State University Image Analysis: Ravishankar Rao, Watson Research Center Nalini Bhusan, Smith College Xiaopin University Illinois Narenda Ahuja, University Illinois Sztander, University Toledo Design: Mark Bajuk, University Illinois Alyce Kaprow, Text: Lin, Pace University John Loustau, Hunter College Jong-Ding Wang, Hunter College Judson Rosebush, Judson Rosebush Sound: Matthew Witten, University Texas Robert Wyatt, Center High Performance Computing Robert Williams, Pace University Rory Stuart, NYNEX Philosophy Michael Heim, Education Foundation DPMA'

'Archive-name: space/net Last-modified: $Date: 93/04/01 14:39:15 NETWORK RESOURCES OVERVIEW reading this document amazing variety computers, much material below apply you. general, however, systems connected \'the net\' fall three categories: Internet, Usenet, BITNET. Electronic mail sent between these networks, other resources available these networks sometimes accessible from other networks email sent special \'servers\'. space astronomy discussion groups actually composed several mechanisms with (mostly) transparent connections between them. mechanism mailing list, which mail sent central distribution point which relays recipients list. addition general lists space (called SPACE Digest Internet users, SPACE BITNET), there number more specialized mailing lists described below. second mechanism Usenet \'netnews\'. This somewhat like bulletin board operating each system which part net. Netnews separates contributions into hundreds different categories based \'group name\'. groups dealing most closely with space topics called \'sci.space.news\', \'sci.space\', \'sci.space.shuttle\', \'sci.astro\', \'talk.politics.space\'. Contributors \'post\' submissions (called \'articles\' netnews terminology) their local machine, which sends other nearby machines. Similarly, articles sent from nearby machines stored locally forwarded other systems, that article posted locally eventually reaches Usenet sites interested receiving news group which article posted. Gateway machines redirect Usenet sci.space group into Internet BITNET mailing lists vice versa- other Usenet groups accessible mailing lists. receive netnews, more flexible interface access wider range material usually make preferred option. MAILING LISTS SPACE Digest main Internet list, being International Space University only second change management over decade). Email space-request@isu.isunet.edu (message body should format \'subscribe space John Public\') join. Note that moderated SPACE Magazine list defunct present lack moderator. copies SPACE Digest since inception 1981 available anonymous FTP. Retrieve \tjulius.cs.qub.ac.uk:pub/SpaceDigestArchive/README further details. Elements moderated list fast distribution Space Shuttle Keplerian Elements before during Shuttle flights. NASA line elements sent list from Kelso, JSC, other sources they released. Email elements-request@telesoft.com join. Digest moderated list discussion Global Positioning System other satellite navigation positioning systems. Email gps-request@esseye.si.com join. Space-investors list information relevant investing space-related companies. Email Vincent Cate (vac@cs.cmu.edu) join. Space-tech list more technical discussion space topics- discussion included esoteric propulsion technologies, asteroid capture, starflight, orbital debris removal, etc. Email space-tech-request@cs.cmu.edu join. Archives digests selected excerpts available anonymous from gs80.sp.cs.cmu.edu (128.2.205.90) /usr/anon/public/space-tech, email space-tech-request don\'t have access. SEDS-L BITNET list members Students Exploration Development Space other interested parties. Email LISTSERV@TAMVM1.BITNET with message saying SUBSCRIBE SEDS-L your name. Email saying INDEX SEDS-L list archive contents. SEDSNEWS BITNET list news items, press releases, shuttle status reports, like. This duplicates material which also found Space Digest, sci.space, sci.space.shuttle, sci.astro. Email LISTSERV@TAMVM1.BITNET saying SUBSCRIBE SEDSNEWS your name join. Email saying INDEX SEDSNEWS list archive contents. Baalke (baalke@kelvin.jpl.nasa.gov) runs mailing list which carries contents sci.space.news Usenet group. Email join list. general note, please mail *request* address mailing list. SPACE Digest, example, relays many inappropriate \'please remove from this list\' messages which sent list address rather than request address. PERIODICALLY UPDATED INFORMATION addition this list, broad variety topical information posted (unless otherwise noted, group sci.space.news created this purpose). Please remember that individuals posting this information performing service readers, don\'t take their time with frivolous requests. ACRONYMS \tGarrett Wollman (wollman@UVM.EDU) posts acronym list around \tfirst each month. ASTRO-FTP LIST \tVeikko Makela (veikko.makela@helsinki.fi) posts monthly list \tanonymous servers containing astronomy space related \tmaterial sci.space sci.astro. AVIATION WEEK \tHenry Spencer (henry@zoo.toronto.edu) posts summaries \tspace-related stories weekly _Aviation Week Space \tTechnology_. BUYING TELESCOPES \tRonnie (ronnie@cisco.com) posts guide buying telescopes \tsci.astro. ELECTRONIC JOURNAL \tDon Barry (don@chara.gsu.edu) posts monthly Electronic Journal \tof Astronomical Society Atlantic sci.astro. FLIGHT INTERNATIONAL \tSwaraj Jeyasingh (sjeyasin@axion.bt.co.uk) posts summaries \tspace-related news from _Flight International_. This focuses more \tnon-US space activities than Aviation Week. LARGE ASTRONOMICAL PROJECTS \tRobert Bunge (rbunge@access.digex.com) posts list describing many \tLarge Telescope Projects Either Being Considered Works \tto sci.astro. NASA HEADLINE NEWS SHUTTLE REPORTS \tPeter (yee@ames.arc.nasa.gov) posts variety NASA material, \tincluding NASA Headline News (with schedule NASA SELECT), \tshuttle payload briefings flight manifests, shuttle \tstatus reports. Usenet users, much this material appears \tthe group sci.space.shuttle. NASA UPDATES \tRon Baalke (baalke@kelvin.jpl.nasa.gov) posts frequent updates from \tJPL, Ames, other centers Ulysses, Gailileo, Pioneer, \tMagellan, Landsat, other missions. ORBITAL ELEMENT SETS \tTS Kelso (tkelso@blackbird.afit.af.mil) posts orbital elements from \tNASA Prediction Bulletins. \tMike Rose (mrose@stsci.edu) posts orbital elements Hubble \tSpace Telescope sci.astro. \tJost Jahn (j.jahn@abbs.hanse.de) posts ephemerides asteroids, \tcomets, conjunctions, encounters sci.astro. SATELLITE LAUNCHES \tRichard Langley (lang@unb.ca) posts SPACEWARN Bulletin, which \tdescribes recent launch/orbital decay information satellites \twhich useful scientific activities. Recent bulletins \tavailable anonymous from nssdca.gsfc.nasa.gov \tANON_DIR:[000000.ACTIVE.SPX]. SHUTTLE MANIFEST \tKen Hollis (gandalf@pro-electric.cts.com) posts compressed version \tof Space Shuttle launch manifest sci.space.shuttle. This \tincludes dates, times, payloads, information \tlaunches landings. SOLAR ACTIVITY \tCary Oler (oler@hg.uleth.ca) posts Solar Terrestrial reports \t(describing solar activity effect Earth) \tsci.space. report issued part from data released \tSpace Enviroment Services Center, Boulder Colorado. intro \tdocument needed understand these reports available \tanonymous from solar.stanford.edu (36.10.0.4) \tpub/understanding_solar_terrestrial_reports. nic.funet.fi \t(128.214.6.100) also this document \t/pub/misc/rec.radio.shortwave/solarreports archive site \tfor reports (please note this site Europe, \tconnection only 56KB). primary archive site, \txi.uleth.ca (142.66.3.29), recently been established will \tactively supported. SOVIET SPACE ACTIVITIES \tGlenn Chapman (glennc@cs.sfu.ca) posts summaries Soviet space \tactivities. SPACE ACTIVIST NEWSLETTER \tAllen Sherzer (aws@iti.org) posts newsletter, Small Step Space Activist, talk.politics.space. describes current \tlegislative activity affecting NASA commercial space activities. SPACE EVENTS CALENDAR \tRon Baalke (baalke@kelvin.jpl.nasa.gov) posts calendar including \tanniversaries, conferences, launch dates, meteor showers \teclipses, other space-related events. SPACE NEWS \tJohn Magliacane (kd2bd@ka2qhd.UUCP) posts SpaceNews (covering \tAMSATs, NOAA other weather satellites, other \tinformation) rec.radio.amateur.misc sci.space. SPACE REPORT \tJonathan McDowell (mcdowell@cfa.harvard.edu) posts Jonathan\'s Space \tReport covering launches, landings, reentries, status reports, \tsatellite activities, etc. TOWARD 2001 \tBev Freed (freed@nss.fidonet.org) posts Toward 2001, weekly \tglobal news summary reprinted from _Space Calendar_ magazine. WARNING ABOUT NON-PUBLIC NETWORKS (Included suggestion Eugene Miya, wrote item) NASA internal system unclassified electronic mail bulletin boards. This system open public use. Specifically, NASA personnel procurement operations regarded with some sensitivity. Contractors must renegotiate their contracts. Fair Open Procurement does look kindly those having inside information. Contractors outsiders caught using this type information expect severe penalities. Unauthorized access attempts subject fine and/or imprisonment accordance with Title USC, Section 1030. fact should should learn unauthorized access, contact NASA personnel. Claims have been made this news group about fraud waste. None have ever been substantiated significant degree. Readers detecting Fraud, Waste, Abuse, Mismanagement should contact NASA Inspector General (24-hours) 800-424-9183 (can anonymous) write \tNASA \tInspector General \tP.O. 23089 \tL\'enfant Plaza Station \tWashington 20024'

'Archive-name: atheism/overview Alt-atheism-archive-name: overview Last-modified: April 1993 Version: Overview Welcome alt.atheism alt.atheism.moderated. This first series regular postings aimed readers newsgroups. Many groups \'controversial\' nature have noticed that readers often come with same questions, mis-statements misconceptions post them net. addition, people often request information which been posted time time again. order down this, alt.atheism groups have series five regular postings under following titles: Alt.Atheism FAQ: Overview Readers Alt.Atheism FAQ: Introduction Atheism Alt.Atheism FAQ: Frequently Asked Questions (FAQ) Alt.Atheism FAQ: Constructing Logical Argument Alt.Atheism FAQ: Atheist Resources This article number Please read numbers before posting. others entirely optional. Usenet, also find helpful read newsgroup news.announce.newusers. articles titled Primer Work With Usenet Community, Answers Frequently Asked Questions about Usenet Hints writing style Usenet particularly relevant. Questions concerning news works best asked news.newusers.questions. unable find articles listed above, Finding Stuff section below. Credits These files could have been written without assistance many readers alt.atheism alt.atheism.moderated. particular, I\'d like thank following people: kck+@cs.cmu.edu (Karl Kluge) perry@dsinc.com (Jim Perry) NETOPRWA@ncsuvm.cc.ncsu.edu (Wayne Aiken) chpetk@gdr.bath.ac.uk (Toby Kelsey) jkp@cs.HUT.FI (Jyrki Kuoppala) geoff.arnold@East.Sun.COM (Geoff Arnold) torkel@sics.se (Torkel Franzen) kmldorf@utdallas.edu (George Kimeldorf) roe2@quads.uchicago.edu (Greg Roelofs) arromdee@jyusenkyou.cs.jhu.edu (Ken Arromdee) madhaus@netcom.com (Maddi Hausmann) J5J@psuvm.psu.edu (John Johnson) dgraham@bmers30.bnr.ca (Douglas Graham) mayne@open.cs.fsu.edu (William Mayne) ajr@bigbird.hri.com (Andy Rosen) stoesser@ira.uka.de (Achim Stoesser) bosullvn@unix1.tcd.ie (Bryan O\'Sullivan) lippard@ccit.arizona.edu (James Lippard) s1b3832@rigel.tamu.edu Baum) ydobyns@phoenix.princeton.edu (York Dobyns) schroede@sdsc.edu (Wayne Schroeder) baldwin@csservera.usna.navy.mil (J.D. Baldwin) D_NIBBY@unhh.unh.edu (Dana Nibby) dempsey@Kodak.COM (Richard Dempsey) jmunch@hertz,elee.calpoly.edu (John David Munch) pdc@dcs.ed.ac.uk (Paul Crowley) rz@mips.complang.tuwien.ac.at (Richard Zach) tycchow@math.mit.edu (Tim Chow) simon@dcs.warwick.ac.uk (Simon Clippingdale) PHIMANEN@cc.helsinki.fi (Pekka Himanen) ...and countless others I\'ve forgotten. These articles free. Truly free. copy them distribute them anyone wish. However, please send changes corrections author, please re-post copies articles alt.atheism- does nobody good have multiple versions same document floating around network. Finding Stuff files *should* somewhere your news system. Here some suggestions what can\'t find them: Check newsgroup alt.atheism. Look subject lines starting with Alt.Atheism FAQ:. Check newsgroup news.answers same subject lines. don\'t find anything steps your news system isn\'t correctly, wish tell your system administrator about problem. have anonymous access, connect rtfm.mit.edu [18.70.0.226]. directory /pub/usenet/alt.atheism, you\'ll find latest versions files there. copying files between networked computers. need help using getting started with FTP, send e-mail mail-server@rtfm.mit.edu with send usenet/news.answers/ftp-list/faq body. There other sites which also carry news.answers postings. article Introduction news.answers newsgroup carries list these sites- article posted regularly news.answers. don\'t have FTP, send mail mail-server@rtfm.mit.edu consisting following lines: send usenet/news.answers/finding-sources send usenet/alt.atheism/faq send usenet/alt.atheism/introduction send usenet/alt.atheism/logic send usenet/alt.atheism/resources (Penultimate resort) Send mail mail-server@mantis.co.uk consisting following lines: send atheism/faq/faq.txt send atheism/faq/logic.txt send atheism/faq/intro.txt send atheism/faq/resource.txt poor overworked modems will send copy files. There\'s other stuff, too- interesting commands help send atheism/index. (Last resort) Mail mathew@mantis.co.uk, post article newsgroup asking files. should only this you\'ve tried above methods they\'ve failed- it\'s nice clutter newsgroup people\'s mailboxes with requests files. it\'s better than posting without reading FAQ, though! instance, people whose email addresses mangled transit don\'t have will probably need assistance obtaining files.

First all, felt that original speed test perhaps less than realistic. movie been using only frames version very first movie created with Compact Video compressor). decided something little longer would give closer real-world results (for better worse). pulled copy 2001: Space Odyssey that recorded while back. About fifteen minutes into movie, there\'s sequence where Earth shuttle approaching space station. Specifically, digitized portion about seconds\' duration, zooming rotating space station. figured this would give reasonable amount movement between frames. increase differences between frames, digitized only frames second, give total frames. captured footage resolution 384*288 pixels with Spigot card Centris (quarter-size resolution from source). then imported into Premiere through Compact Video compressor, keeping frame rate. created versions movie: scaled 320*240 resolution, other 160*120 resolution. used default 2.00 quality setting Premiere 2.0.1, specified frame every frames. then 320*240 movie through same Speed Test program used results I\'d been reporting earlier. Result: playback rate over frames second. That\'s right, getting much higher result than with that first short test movie. Just fun, copied 320*240 movie external hard disk Quantum LP105S), from there. This time playback rate only about frames second. Obviously 230MB internal hard disk (also Quantum) significant contributor speed playback. modified speed test program allow specification optional scaling factors, tried playing back 160*120 movie scaled 320*240 size. This time playback speed over fps. Clearly, poster observed poor performance scaled playback seeing QuickTime action, 1.5. I\'d tests with QuickTime 1.0, don\'t think it\'s entirely compatible with Centris System 7.1... Unscaled, playback rate 160*120 movie over fps. other thing tried saving versions 320*240 movie with preferred playback rates greater than 1.0, seeing well they played from within MoviePlayer with QuickTime\'s normal synchronized playback). preferred rate fps) didn\'t work well: playback very jerky. Compare this with speed test, which achieved with ease. can\'t believe that QuickTime\'s synchronization code would this much overhead: think slowdown coming from system\'s task switching. preferred rate fps) seemed work fine: couldn\'t evidence stutter. fps) *think* could slight stutter, with four frames every second, hard tell. guess could recreating movies with longer interval between frames, make stutter more noticeable. course, this will also improve compression slightly, which should speed playback performance even more...'
